p: The seroprevalence in goats sampled during February—April 2017, determined using SNT, was 31.7% (33/104; 95% CI: 22.9–41.6%) ( Table 2). Although seroprevalence appeared to increase with age, this was not statistically significant ( P = 0.549) in the multiple logistic regression model ( S2 Table), nor was there a significant difference between sexes ( P = 0.139). The overall seroprevalence in cattle and goats varied substantially across the study area ( Fig 3), with foci of high seroprevalence along the Pongolo River, but was not clearly linked to the presence of wetlands.
